tooltip.title: repeatedly execute code while true
tooltip.body: repeatedly executes the code block inside the while loop as long as the condition remains `True`.

tips.title: infinite loop
tips.example:
while True :
	print("an infinite loop")

tips.title: count from 0 to 10
tips.example:
i = 0
while i < 10:
	print(i)
	i = i + 1

tips.title: compare to scratch's repeat until block
tips.text: the `while` loop in Python compared to the `repeat until` block in Scratch: the `while` loop in Python repeats code as long as the condition is `True`, and stops when the condition becomes `False`. However, the `repeat until` block in Scratch repeats code as long as the condition is `False`, and stops when the condition becomes `True`.

explanations.text: i is less than 3 so the condition holds true
i is no longer less than 3 so the condition is false
should execute the next line after the while loop

tooltip.title: loop through a sequence of elements
tooltip.body: executes a set of statements for each element in a sequence (like a `range`, a `list`, or a `string`).

tips.title: for loop inputs
tips.text: for loops have two inputs: a variable name, and a sequence of items. the created variable is used to hold the current item, and the sequence is the list of items to go through.

tips.title: for loop as a counter
tips.text: for loops can be used with the `range` function to work like a counter

tips.title: using a for loop to go through a list
go through a list of items
go through a sequence of numbers
go through a list of items using indices
go through every character of a string

tooltip.title: Create Iterable Sequence
tooltip.body: Generates a sequence of numbers from 0 to the provided input. Usually used with a for loop.

tips.example:
for i in range(10):
	print(i)

toolbox.title: print(message: any)

tooltip.title: Display Text in Console
tooltip.body: Displays the textual value of its input in the console.

toolbox.invalidTooltip: Can only be inserted on an empty line within a loop.

tips.example:
print(123)
print("Hello World!")

a = "abc"
print(a)

tooltip.title: Ask User for Textual Input
tooltip.body: Displays a message that prompts the user to enter some text. The entered text will be returned.

tips.example:
name = input("Hi! Whatâ€™s your name?")
print(name)

tooltip.title: Get Length of List or Text
tooltip.body: Returns the number of items in an object, or the number of characters in a text.

tips.example:
greeting = "Hello World!"
a = len(greeting)
print(a)

items = [1, 2, 3]
a = len(items)
print(a)

tooltip.title: Insert Choice from List
tooltip.body: Randomly selects and returns an item from the given list. Needs to be imported from the random module.

tooltip.title: Generate a Random Number
tooltip.body: Returns a randomly generated number from the given range. Needs to be imported from the random module.

tips.example:
a = randint(0, 10)
print(a)

tooltip.title: Insert Break inside Loop
tooltip.body: Stops the innermost running loop (for, while) and breaks out of it.

tips.title: break out of a while loop on some condition

explanations.text: variable i is defined and set to 0
should repeat the while statements if i < 10
i is 0 and less than 10 -> should repeat
i is 0, so i + 1 is 1
i becomes 1
should enter the if statements if i equals 3
i is 1 so shouldn't enter the if
i is 1, so i + 1 is 2
should continue repeating because i is 1
i becomes 2
i is not equal to 3
should continue repeating because i is 2
i is 2, so i + 1 is 3
i becomes 3
is equal to 3 -> should enter if
break out of the current loop
won't check the while condition as we used break
will print 'done'

tooltip.title: Insert If Statement
tooltip.body: Will only execute the indented block of code below it when the condition is true

tips.title: check the value of a variable

toolbox.invalidTooltip: Can only be inserted directly below an if or elif statement.
toolbox.title: else statement

tooltip.title: Insert Else Statement
tooltip.body: Can be used after an if or an elif statement. will execute its block of code when the if and the elif statements were not true

toolbox.invalidTooltip: Can only be inserted directly below an if statement.
toolbox.title: elif statement

tooltip.title: Insert Elif Statement
tooltip.body: Short for else-if; adds another case to an existing if statement. The `elif` will only run when previous `if` or `elif` statement is false

tips.title: using elif after an if statement
using elif after another elif statement

tooltip.title: Create Variable Assignment
tooltip.body: Allows to store a value and give it a name to reference it by later.

tips.example:
name = "John"
print(name)

tips.text: A variable is created the moment you first assign a value to it.

tips.title: variable naming
bullets: Variable names can only contain letters, numbers, and underscores
Variable names are case-sensitive ("x" and "X" are different)
A variable name must start with a letter or the underscore character
A variable name cannot start with a number

tooltip.title: Reference Variable
tooltip.body: Refers to the value stored in the specified variable.

tips.example:
name = "John"
print(name)

tips.text: References only exist for variables that have been created or assigned a value.
Reference names follow the same rules as variable names.

tooltip.title: Add Value to Variable
tooltip.body: Adds the value on the right-hand side of the += sign to the specified variable and stores the result in the variable.

tips.example:
a = 2
a += 2
print(a)

tooltip.title: Subtract Value from Variable
tooltip.body: Subtracts the value on the right-hand side of the -= sign from the specified variable and stores the result back in the variable.

tips.example:
a = 5
a -= 2
print(a)

tooltip.title: Multiply Variable by Value
tooltip.body: Multiplies the variable by the value on the right-hand side of the *= sign and stores the result back in the variable.

tips.example:
a = 5
a *= 2
print(a)

tooltip.title: Divide Variable by Value
tooltip.body: Divides the variable by the value given on the right-hand side of the /= sign and stores the result back in the variable.

tips.example:
a = 10
a /= 2
print(a)

tooltip.title: Insert a Number
tooltip.body: Inserts a number and edit its value.

tips.example:
age = 21
print(age)
print(21)

tooltip.title: Insert a Text
tooltip.body: Inserts an editable text that is wrapped by double quotes.

tips.example:
fruit = "apple"
print(fruit)
print("apple")

tooltip.title: Insert Formattable Text
tooltip.body: Inserts an editable, formattable text; used along with the {} operator to include non-static values and variables inside the text.

tips.example:
age = 16
name = "Alex"
print(f'My name is {name} and I am {age} years old')

tooltip.title: Insert Editable List
tooltip.body: Inserts an empty list. Press comma before or after each item to add a new empty item.

tips.example:
a = []
print(a) # a is an empty list
a = [1, 2, 3]
print(a) # a is a list with three items

a = ["cat", "dog", "parrot"]
b = [1, "cat", true]
c = [1, [1, "dog"], "cat", [true]]

tooltip.title: Insert Addition
tooltip.body: Adds the values to the left and right of the operator.

tips.example:
a = 2
b = 5
print((a + b))

a = "hello"
b = "world"
print((a + " " + b))

tooltip.title: Insert Subtraction
tooltip.body: Subtracts the value to the right of the operator from the value to the left.

tips.example:
a = 20
b = 10
print((a - b))

tooltip.title: Insert Negative Number
tooltip.body: Negates the value to the right of the operator.

tips.example:
a = -2
b = -5
print((a + b))

tooltip.title: Insert Multiplication
tooltip.body: Multiplies the values to the left and right of the operator.

tips.example:
a = 2
b = 5
print((b * a))

tooltip.title: Insert Division
tooltip.body: Divides the values to the left of the operator by the right value.

tips.example:
a = 2
b = 10
print((b / a))

tooltip.title: Insert Floor Division
tooltip.body: Performs integer division (remainder is discarded and always result is always rounded down) between the values to the left and right of the operator.

tips.example:
a = 2
b = 7
print((b / a))

tooltip.title: Insert Modulo
tooltip.body: Calculates the remainder of the division between the values to the left and right of the operator.

tips.example:
print((29 % 5)) # prints 4
print((28 % 5)) # prints 3
print((27 % 5)) # prints 2
print((26 % 5)) # prints 1
print((25 % 5)) # prints 0

tooltip.title: Is Equal?
tooltip.body: Compares two values. Returns True if they are equal; returns False otherwise.

tips.example:
a = 5
b = 5
while a == b:
	a += 1
print(a)
print(a)

tooltip.title: Is Not Equal?
tooltip.body: Compares two values. Returns True if they are not equal; returns False otherwise.

tips.example:
a = 1
b = 5
while a != b:
	a += 1
print(a)
print(a)

tooltip.title: Is Less Than?
tooltip.body: Compares two values. Returns True if the left value is less than the right value.

tips.example:
a = 1
b = 5
while a < b:
	a += 1
print(a)
print(a)

tooltip.title: Is Less Than or Equal?
tooltip.body: Compares two values. Returns True if the left value is less than or equal to the right value.

tips.example:
a = 2
b = 3
 c = 2
 if a <= b:
	print("a is less than b")

if c <= a:
	print("c is equal to a")

a = 1
b = 5
while a <= b:
	a += 1
print(a)
print(a)

tooltip.title: Is Greater Than?
tooltip.body: Compares two values. Returns True if the left value is greater than the right value.

tips.example:
a = 1
b = 5
while b > a:
	a += 1
print(a)
print(a)

tooltip.title: Is Greater Than or Equal?
tooltip.body: Compares two values. Returns True if the left value is greater than or equal to the right value.

tips.example:
a = 2
b = 3
 c = 2
 if b >= a:
	print("b is greater than a")

if c >= a:
	print("c is equal to a")

a = 1
b = 5
while b >= a:
	a += 1
print(a)
print(a)

tooltip.title: Inside?
tooltip.body: Returns True if the left item is inside the right item; returns False otherwise.

tips.example:
from random import randint
a = randint(1, 10)
b = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
if a in b:
	print("a is inside b")

if a not in b:
	print("a is not inside b")

tooltip.title: Not Inside?
tooltip.body: Returns True if the left item is not inside the right item; returns False otherwise.

tips.example:
from random import randint
a = randint(1, 10)
b = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
if a in b:
	print("a is inside b")

if a not in b:
	print("a is not inside b")

tooltip.title: And Operator
tooltip.body: Used to combine conditional expressions. Results in True if both the left and right expressions are True; returns False otherwise.

tips.example:
a = 5
b = 7
c=2

if ((a > c) and (b > c)):
	print("Both expressions are true.")

tooltip.title: Or Operator
tooltip.body: Used to combine conditional expressions. Results in True as long as at least one of the left and right expressions is True; returns False otherwise.

tips.example:
a = 5
b = 7
c=2

if ((a > c) and (b < c)):
	print("Only the first expression is true.")

tooltip.title: Not Operator
tooltip.body: Flips the truth value of an expression. True becomes False, and False becomes True.

tooltip.title: Insert True
tooltip.body: Inserts a True boolean value.

tooltip.title: Insert False
tooltip.body: Inserts a False boolean value.

tooltip.title: Insert Addition
tooltip.body: Adds the values to the left and right of the operator.

tips.example:
a = 2
b = 5
print((a + b))

a = "hello"
b = "world"
print((a + " " + b))

tooltip.title: Insert Addition
tooltip.body: Adds the values to the left and right of the operator.

tips.example:
a = 2
b = 5
print((a + b))

body.paragraph: Converts the passed object to a text object. Useful when comparing values of different types and one of them is a text value. This type of conversion is called a cast because it is temporary.
In the above example you would not be able to compare a to c before performing the conversion.

tooltip.title: Converts Anything to Text
tooltip.body: Converts the passed object to its textual representation.

tips.example:
a = 2
c = "2"
print(str(a) == c)

tooltip.title: Converts Text to Number
tooltip.body: Converts a number text to an actual number. Extremely useful when trying to input numbers from the user.

tips.example:
a = "2"
b = "5"
text_add = a + b
number_add = int(a) + int(b)

tooltip.title: Imports A Function
tooltip.body: Loads a particular function from a module.

tips.example:
from random import randint
from random import choice

from random import randint
print(randint(1, 6))
